body.p: I am sincerely pleased with every mark of your kindness, & as such I look upon your last letter in particular. I feel for the sorrow you have felt, & yet I can not wish to lessen it: that would be to rob you of the best part of your nature, to efface from your mind the tender memory of a Father's love, & deprive the Dead of that just & grateful tribute wch his goodness demanded from you.

I must however remind you, how happy it was for him, that you were with him to the last; that he was sensible perhaps of your care, when every other sense was vanishingâ€“he might have lost you last year, might have seen you go before him at a time, when all the ills of helpless old-age were coming upon him, & (tho' not destitute of the attention & tenderness of others) yet destitute of your attention & your tenderness. May God preserve you my best Friend! & (Long after my eyes are closed) give you that last satisfaction in the gratitude & affection of a Son, wch you have given your Father.

closer.salute:
I am ever
Most truly & entirely
Yours
